questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his mother. She noticed her son has recurrent episodes of giving a blank look while playing ball games. No history is suggestive of any development delay in the child. No history of loss of consciousness and the child resumes play soon after within a few seconds. EEG performed on the child shows a characteristic 3Hz spike and waveform. The most appropriate treatment, in this case, would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Valproate Multiple episodes of blank look in a day with normal post-ictal phase in a 6-year -old suggests the diagnosis of Absence seizure and 3Hz spike and waveform on EEG confirms the same. Valproate is the drug of choice for Absence seizure.

Highyeild:

Absence seizure- Age- 2 to 6 yr 30% → GTCs/Myoclonic epilepsy Blank /vacant stare- seconds Unawareness → during ictal → nonresponsive Neuro examination/MRI- normal One of the ways to elicit and document absence seizure is hyperventilation. EEG- 3 spikes wave pattern EEG- 3 spikes wave pattern EEG showing 3 per second (3Hz) spike and wave discharges typical of absence epilepsy Treatment - Valproate Ethosuximide

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B.Ethosuximide- is preferred in children under 3 years of age due to adverse effects of Valproate -fulminant hepatitis. Option: C & D . Phenytoin and Carbamazepine are useful in GTCS.

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old boy with a known case of Absence seizure was prescribed Drug X. Within 2 months, the child presented to the emergency with yellowish discoloration of eyes, passing high color urine, and altered sensorium all of which started 1 day back. On examination, the child has jaundice, multiple bruises over their hands and flanks, poor GCS, and flapping tremors. Urgent LFT panel showed the following: Bilirubin- 15 mg% AST- 1000 U ALT -1450 U PT- 60 sec INR- 5 Ammonia was markedly increased A diagnosis of fulminant hepatitis was made. Regarding the adverse effect profile of drug X which statement is incorrect.

options.label: A
options.text: Long-term use may increase the chances of PCOS in young girls

options.label: B
options.text: The given side effect is very rare with drug X

options.label: C
options.text: Bruises in a child could also be attributed to low platelet count

options.label: D
options.text: In case a pregnant female is prescribed Drug X, she should be supplemented with 400 micrograms of folic acid and fetal growth surveillance USG.

questions.correct_answer: D. In case a pregnant female is prescribed Drug X, she should be supplemented with 400 micrograms of folic acid and fetal growth surveillance USG.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In case a pregnant female is prescribed Drug X, she should be supplemented with 400 micrograms of folic acid and fetal growth surveillance USG. This is an incorrect statement .The drug X is Valproate. A pregnant patient taking valproate (high risk for NTD ) needs 4mg i.e. 4000 micrograms of folic acid supplementation. In this case, the drug used was As the patient is suffering from fulminant hepatitis ( children <3 yr are at high risk to develop fulminant hepatitis) , raised serum ammonia, and Thrombocytopenia (rash).

Highyeild:

Sodium Valproate Mechanism of action- Blocks Na+ Blocks T type calcium channel Increases GABA Decreases glutamate Uses: Drug of choice GTCS Myoclonic seizure Absence seizure Dravet syndrome LGS-Lennox gastaut syndrome Status epilepticus Non-epileptic use Bipolar Depression Migraine DOC- rapid cycler Bipolar disorder. Adverse effects- VALPROATE V -Vomiting A -Alopecia L-Liver toxicity Fulminant hepatitis (very rare) <3 yr old is at high risk for Fulminant hepatitis P -Pancreatitis PCOD R- Requires Therapeutic Drug Monitoring Rash O -Obesity A -Ammonia increase Carnitine is DOC for Valproate hyperammonemia T -Teratogenic → NTD Folate 4mg/day Thrombocytopenia E-Enzyme inhibitor

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & C are true statements about Valporate.

Extraedge:

Preconception management of epilepsy Confirm the epilepsy diagnosis Start folic acid 1 to 5 mg/day Use the most effective Antiepileptic medication at the lowest dose Avoid valproate, topiramate, and phenobarbital Establish baseline serum drug concentration.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presenting with developmental regression with characteristic Salaam seizures and EEG showing a pattern of hypsarrhythmia. Drug of Choice would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ACTH Patient is <2yr old with a triad of West Syndrome or infantile spasms . ACTH therapy has minimal side effects and shows a good response in reversing hypsarrhythmia . Cessation of hypsarrhythmia is more with ACTH than Vigabatrin hence hormonal therapy is preferred.

Highyeild:

Infantile spasms/West syndrome <2 years 3-9 months Developmental delays Episodes → spasm EEG-Hypsarrhythmia- Bizarre slow wave Etiology- Perinatal asphyxia Brain anomalies→ Lissencephaly Infants West syndrome Triad Salaam spells(sudden dropping of the head and flexion of arm) Developmental retardation Hypsarrhythmia Treatment- ACTH Tuberous sclerosis→ Vigabatrin

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Vigabatrin -Use of Vigabatrin in West syndrome is limited only if the child has associated Tuberous Sclerosis. Option: C and D . Clonazepam and ethosuximide have no role in the treatment of West syndrome.

questions.text: Concerning an indication of brain imaging in a patient with epilepsy, pick up the incorrect statement:
questions.correct_answer: A. Epilepsy before 15 years of age
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epilepsy before 15 years of age

Highyeild:

Imaging cannot establish a diagnosis of epilepsy but identifies any structural cause. It is not required if a confident diagnosis of a recognized epilepsy syndrome (e.g. juvenile myoclonic epilepsy ) can be made. CT : Structural cause of epilepsy, MRI : Subtle changes such as hippocampal sclerosis, may direct or inform surgical intervention. Indication for brain imaging in epilepsy Epilepsy starting after the age of 16 yrs Seizures having focal features clinically EEG showing a focal seizure source Control of seizures difficult or deteriorating

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B, C & D are indications for Brain imaging in patients with epilepsy.

Extraedge:

Seizure: Clinical manifestation of abnormal and excessive excitation of a population of cortical neurons. Epilepsy: A tendency towards recurrent seizures unprovoked by systemic neurological insults. Epilepsy is a disease of the brain defined by any of the following conditions- At least 2 unprovoked (reflex) seizures occurring >24 hr apart. One unprovoked (or reflex )seizure and a probability of further seizures similar to the general recurrence risk (at least 60%) after two unprovoked seizures, occurring over the next 10 years. Diagnosis of epilepsy syndrome. Epilepsy is considered resolved for individuals who had an age-dependent epilepsy syndrome but are now past the applicable age or those who have remained seizure-free for the last 10 years, with no seizure medicines for the last 5 years.

questions.text: The commonest presentation of neurocysticercosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seizures

Highyeild:

Neurocysticercosis Most common Central nervous system Parasitic infection is Neurocysticercosis. Commonest presentation of Neurocysticercosis is Seizures. These seizures may be generalized, focal, or Jacksonian. Seizures are associated with inflammation surrounding cysticerci in the brain parenchyma. There is a wide variety of Neurocysticercosis depending on the intensity of the infestation, the localization of cysticerci, and the degree of inflammatory reaction . Cysticercosis is an infection with the larval stage (cysticercosis cellulose) of solium(Pig tapeworm) The lesion of Neurocysticercosis is readily visualized by MRI or CT scan. Parenchymal brain calcification is the most common finding on (Starry sky appearance) Brain parenchyma is the most common site of Neurocysticercosis. The ventricular system is the 2nd most common site of Most common sites of Neurocysticercosis- Parenchymatous >intraventricular> subarachnoid >spinal >orbital. These cysts are located in order of frequency in CNS(neurological manifestations are the most common) Subcutaneous tissue Striated muscle Globe of the eye Treatment Antiparasitic drugs- Albendazole Praziquantel Albendazole and praziquantel combination with more than two cystic lesions. with multiple subarachnoid cysticerci. may exacerbate the inflammatory response around the deadly parasite, thereby exacerbating seizures or hydrocephalus as well. Monitoring of the patient High Dose glucocorticoids should be used during treatment. Because glucocorticoids induce first-pass metabolism of praziquantel and may decrease its antiparasitic effect, cimetidine should be co-administered to inhibit praziquantel metabolism. Hydrocephalus treatment- Removal of the cysticercus via neurosurgery via neuro-endoscopy Microdissection using an open craniotomy Ventriculoperitoneal shunting + prolonged courses of antiparasitic drugs Patient requiring prolonged therapy- Methotrexate Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors Steroid-sparing agents Diffuse cerebral edema/Elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions- Glucocorticoids(a mainstay of therapy) Antiparasitic drugs should be avoided For ocular and spinal medullary lesions, drug-induced inflammation may cause irreversible damage. Ocular disease Surgery Spinal disease Medical or surgical therapy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B,C & D are incorrect.

Extraedge:

TABLE 235-1 Revised Diagnostic Criteria for Neurocysticercosis 1. Absolute criteria a. Histologic demonstration of the parasite from a biopsy of a brain or spinal cord lesion b. Visualization of subretinal cysticercus c. Conclusive demonstration of a scolex within a cystic lesion on neuroimaging studies 2. Neuroimaging criteria a. Major neuroimaging criteria Cystic lesions without a discernible scolex, typical small enhancing lesions, multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications b. Confirmative neuroimaging criteria Resolution of cystic lesions spontaneously or after suicidal drug therapy Migration of ventricular cysts documented on sequential neuroimaging studies c. Minor neuroimaging criteria Obstructive hydrocephalus or abnormal enhancement of basal leptomeninges 3. Clinical/exposure criteria a. Major clinical/exposure criteria Detection of specific anticysticercal antibodies (e.g., by enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot [EITB]) or cysticerci antigens by well- standardized immunodiagnostic tests Cysticercosis outside the central nervous system Evidence of a household contact with T. solium infection b. Minor clinical/exposure criteria Clinical manifestations suggestive of neurocysticercosis Individuals coming from or living in an area where cysticercosis is endemic Diagnosis is confirmed by one absolute criterion, by two major criteria or one major and one confirmatory neuroimaging criteria plus any clinical/exposure criterion, or by one major neuroimaging criterion plus two clinical/exposure criteria (including at least one major clinical/exposure criterion), together with the exclusion of other pathologies producing similar neuroimaging findings. A probable diagnosis is supported by one major neuroimaging criterion plus any two clinical/ exposure criteria or by one minor neuroimaging criterion plus at least one major clinical/exposure criterion.
